speaker: Patient
text: I’m, uh, really scared, doctor. The nurse showed me the sema-glu-tide pen, but once I’m home I forget which click is the actual dose, and it’s so expensive for me.

speaker: Patient
text: My morning sugars are still running 190, sometimes 200, even though I take the metformin and that other one, glipi-zide, unless it upsets my stomach. I feel like nothing is working anymore for my body.

speaker: Patient
text: I heard Medicare stops paying after a certain amount, the donut something, and I don’t know how I’ll afford weekly shots when that happens later.

speaker: Clinician
text: Let me make sure I understand, Mrs. Delgado: you’re comfortable with the injection steps now, but you’re anxious about the click counts, your stomach with glipizide, and long-term cost, correct?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, and I, um, sometimes forget the evening glipizide because I fall asleep in front of the TV. Then I feel guilty and double up next day.

speaker: Clinician
text: I appreciate your honesty. First, please don’t ever double up; that can plunge sugar too low. Instead, just wait for the next scheduled dose. Second, regarding the pen: after you twist to 0.25 milligrams you’ll hear one solid click; the second click only confirms delivery into the skin.

speaker: Patient
text: So if I miss it, just skip? Okay. Will the nausea everyone talks about hit me right away, or after more doses?

speaker: Patient
text: And the price—my neighbor said she orders from a Canadian website. I don’t want to do anything illegal, but I don’t want to choose between pills and groceries.

speaker: Clinician
text: Understood. Short term, nausea usually peaks the first two weeks, then eases. Sip ginger tea, eat small meals. We’ll only increase the dose if your stomach tolerates it and sugars stay high later on.

speaker: Clinician
text: About cost: the manufacturer offers a patient-assistance card until you enter the donut hole; my nurse can enroll you online in minutes for free.

speaker: Clinician
text: For the gap months, some Part D plans cover a lower-dose pen we can prescribe twice weekly, cutting your yearly spending half.

speaker: Clinician
text: I’ll also flag our pharmacist to print a large-font, step-by-step sticker for your pen, so you’re not guessing clicks alone at night anymore there.

speaker: Patient
text: That would help a lot. If I keep my sugars under 150, will we ever stop the glipizide? It makes me shaky sometimes still.

speaker: Patient
text: Also—sorry, last thing—my granddaughter wants me to travel for her graduation in June. Can I carry the pen on the plane without refrigeration the whole time there?
